item.title: Bad Blood [John Carreyrou]
Lean Startups vs. VC Money
item.description: 20 years later, JetBrains is valued at $7b without taking VC money. HN users praise JetBrains for being user-focused, and the prevailing argument is that VC money comes with growth-hacking attached. [] Is the Lean Startup Dead? Katzenberg (Paramount, Disney Studios & DreamWorks) has raised $1.75b for NewTV, a startup banking on consumers wanting a subscription for 10-minute programs on mobile. They renamed to quibi.com/ . At least that makes them more searchable on Google.

item.title: On Running a Business
item.description: Consultants are not well suited for strategy (you probably have a deeper understanding). They are also an expensive way of proving your point to management. However, they are good for emergency horsepower, e.g. data analysis, and for primary research within your industry (they probably have a broader understanding). [] When not to hire strategy consultants - notes from ex-BCG consultant. item.description: Startups vs. Incumbents Why Do Competitive Edges Die? item.title: APIs Are Not In the Efficiency Business
item.description: CityFlo Reduces Google Maps API Bill by 94% [] Google Directions API limited their free tier . CityFlo uses this API to calculate ETAs. Initially, CityFlo queried the API every time a stop was registered. This was the problem. The number of API calls should be dependent on the stops themselves, not the buses. For an MVP, sure - make that query - but if you’re running a growing business, those calls add up!

item.title: AT&T to pay $60m in settlement for slowing cellphone data on unlimited plans
item.description: AT&T to pay $60m in settlement for slowing cellphone data on unlimited plans. Complaint filed in 2014 by the FTC: AT&T charged smartphone users for ‘unlimited’ data plans, but throttled them after ~2GB within a month. AT&T: None of these allegations were ever proved in court. We were fully prepared to defend ourselves, but decided settling was in the best interests of consumers.

item.title: The Shady Economics of Buy-One-Get-One Free Deals [The Hustle]
item.description: The Shady Economics of Buy-One-Get-One Free Deals. Zachary Crockett. The Hustle. https://thehustle.co/are-buy-one-get-one-free-deals-worth-it/ . Feb 17, 2019. BOGO goods are usually low-demand, non-efficient, lacking in quality and/or close to the expiration date. The BOGO deal is usually a 50% discount off of the manufacturer’s suggested retail price (MSRP). And oftentimes, this price is artificially marked up to begin with. MyPillow offered BOGO deal on their pillows, but really just doubled the price of the first pillow.

item.title: Monopolistic Tendencies in the Prescription Glasses Industry
item.description: Luxottica - Queen of the Seven Kingdoms [] Luxottica owns and licenses Armani, Brooks Brothers, Burberry, Chanel, Coach, DKNY, Dolce & Gabbana, Michael Kors, Oakley, Oliver Peoples, Persol, Polo Ralph Lauren, Ray-Ban, Tiffany, Valentino, Vogue and Versace. item.title: The Average Age of a Successful Startup Founder is 45 [Harvard Business]
item.description: The Average Age of a Successful Startup Founder is 45. Harvard Business Review. https://hbr.org/2018/07/research-the-average-age-of-a-successful-startup-founder-is-45 . Jul 11, 2018. There’s a variation among industries: software tends to 40, while oil/gas/biotech tends to 47. Even Gates, Jobs, Bezos, Brin & Page had their growth rates peak when they were middle aged. Different definitions of success, e.g. employment growth, sales growth, IPO/acquisition, came to the same conclusion. VCs may not be looking for growth potential.

item.title: Why I Love B2B over B2C [Atrium]
item.description: Why I Love B2B over B2C. Justin Kan. Atrium. https://www.atrium.co/blog/b2b-vs-b2c/ . Jul 11, 2018. B2B customers will actually pay for your product. You have a clear execution path - they’ll tell you and pay for features. Companies don’t quickly flip flop between products. Consumers are too price sensitive and finicky. B2B customers are rational, and thus understandable. They care about whether a solution solves their problem and if the solution is important enough to pay for.

item.title: Do Things That Don't Scale [Paul Graham]
item.description: Do Things That Don't Scale. Paul Graham. http://www.paulgraham.com/ds.html . Jul 1, 2013. Recruit manually. Don’t send links. Set them up on the spot. Ask how big the startup would be if you did the right things, not whether you’re currently changing the world. Delight your initial customers. Tim Cook can’t send handwritten notes, but you can. If you can solve the problem manually, do so while gradually automating the most pressing bottlenecks.

item.title: The Submarine [Paul Graham]
item.description: The Submarine. Paul Graham. http://www.paulgraham.com/submarine.html . Apr 1, 2005. Many people rely on social proof to form opinions; therein lies the power of PR. PR firms are not dishonest for they need good reputation with news outlets. But PR firms serve overworked reporters with selective truths. The firms feed the same story to different publications at once. Readers see similar stories in multiple places and assume a new trend has come.
